title: Paul-Adrien Bourdaloue
text:
Paul Adrien Bourdaloue (4 January 1798, <a href="Bourges">Bourges</a> - 21 June 1868, <a href="Bourges">Bourges</a>) was a French civil engineer and topographer, who proposed the first orthometric <a href="levelling">levelling</a> of France.
Life.
Head of the <a href="Corps%20des%20Ponts%20et%20Chauss%C3%A9es">Corps des Ponts et Chaussées</a>, then engineer-resident of the Chemins de fer du Gard, from 1847 he carried out the <a href="levelling">levelling</a> of the area of the future <a href="Suez%20Canal">Suez Canal</a> in Egypt at the request of the engineer <a href="Louis%20Maurice%20Adolphe%20Linant%20de%20Bellefonds">Linant de Bellefonds</a>. During this process he and others noted that the difference in levels between the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> and <a href="Red%20Sea">Red Sea</a> was negligible, contrary to the conclusions of <a href="Napoleon%20I%20of%20France">Bonaparte</a>'s engineers on the <a href="French%20Campaign%20in%20Egypt%20and%20Syria">Egyptian Expedition</a> such as <a href="Jacques-Marie%20Le%20P%C3%A8re">Jacques-Marie Le Père</a>.
In 1857, he was commissioned to move onto the <a href="general%20levelling%20of%20France">general levelling of mainland France</a>. From 1857 to 1863, he laid out a network of 15,000 <a href="Survey%20marker">iron seals</a> across France, providing the country's first level-lines.
He was <a href="mayor">maire</a>-adjoint of the town of <a href="Bourges">Bourges</a>. In 1865, he entrusted to the architect <a href="Albert%20Tissandier">Albert Tissandier</a> the design of a <a href="water%20tower">château d'eau</a> at <a href="S%C3%A9raucourt">Séraucourt</a>, still visible. He is buried in the cimetière des Capucins at Bourges.
